title: Friday, 10th June, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
BE

Hey. Hello, hi, good morning.

BE

And that the Twitter autopost that's meant to go up when we post things is running at a 20 minute delay.

BE

It's not that we're deliberately sabotaging our viewing figures .... but .......

11:04 am
BE

Anyway, just me today. Paul's off somewhere.

BE

(Which might explain why we've had house price crash and hardcore porn on the homepage already his morning.)

BE

It's therefore up to me to pick a picture.

11:05 am
BE

Business sections have three default pictures: a man in a tie, a woman in a frock or a big rock.

BE

We'll go for option three.

BE

11:05 am
BE

The Cullinan Dream, no less.

BE

$25.365m of big rock.

BE

The largest Fancy Intense Blue Diamond ever to be auctioned, as featured as the centrepiece of Christie’s Magnificent Jewels auction in New York held on 9 June

11:06 am
BE

"Christie’s Magnificent Jewels"

BE

 In June 2014, Petra Diamonds announced the discovery of a 122.52 carat blue diamond from South Africa’s

Cullinan mine, which was cut into four notably sized diamonds, of which the Cullinan Dream is the largest

 Petra Diamonds will receive a 15 percent share in the diamond sales proceeds after expenses

BE

Coo!

11:06 am
BE

Set with a cut-cornered rectangular mixed-cut fancy intense blue diamond, weighing approximately 24.18 carats, flanked on either side by a tapered baguette-cut diamond, weighing a total of approximately 2.36 carats, ring size 6, mounted in platinum, inscribed 'Cullinan Dream'.

The Cullinan Dream, named for its captivating and celestial beauty, has been graded by the Gemological Institute of America as a fancy intense blue diamond and classified as Type IIb. Type IIb diamonds are very rare and account for less than one-half of one percent of all diamonds found in nature. These diamonds contain a small amount of the element boron trapped in the crystal carbon structure during their formation that can give rise to a blue or grey coloration.

BE

Captivating and celestial.

BE

11:07 am
BE

Wait! Sorry.

BE

Wrong picture.

BE

That's not the Cullinan Dream.

11:07 am
BE

It's a Genuine 4ct Swiss Blue Topaz 925 Solid Sterling Silver Emerald Cut Ring

BE

That I found on eBay this morning, for $39.99 or nearest offer.

BE

11:08 am
BE

They're both nice though, right?

BE

Both offering excellent value for money, in their own ways.

BE

And I guess it's personal taste whether the former's 63,412,400% more captivating and celestial than the latter.

Etc.

undefined
11:14 am
BE

Story wise, we have the recruiters.

BE

(@Soundbuy: when I checked half an hour ago, garbage. Not sure currently.)

BE

Big note out of Deutsche

11:15 am
BE

Saying the decline of staffers are in both cyclical and structural

BE

BE

The cyclical stuff is well known, and we've plenty of material in the archive about the sense of selling x months ahead of the peak, or whatever.

11:16 am
BE

Deutsche adds in the structural profit decline.

BE

"Social sourcing" (?) and "recruitment process outsourcing" (?) "have eaten away at the available gross profit pool."

BE

So sell Hays. And sell Page.

11:17 am
BE

Along with Randstad, Adecco and all the others, which DB already had on sells.

BE

We believe staffing stocks will continue to fall on earnings downgrades and we
model a much worse outcome for 2017 than the market. Sell.

BE

Too early to look through the downgrades and past the structural issues

Staffing and recruitment companies have already de-rated and as such it is
tempting to try and look through the downgrades, however, we believe it is too
early to say that a downturn is “in the price” until the earnings downgrades
have started to come through. Our concerns are both cyclical and structural.
We believe that current multiples do not reflect a likely cyclical downturn in
earnings over 16e and into 17e and do not reflect the structural and
demographic pressures on conversion rates.

11:18 am
BE

Downgrading EPS, downgrading recommendations to Sell

We now model 2017e as a down year for earnings. There has been a
synchronous rise in staffing and recruitment markets and with the number of
job vacancies in the UK, US, Japan and Germany all above their previous
peaks we see considerable risk of a substantial earnings correction in 17e. We
cut our Dec 17e EPS by 25% for Page and by 24% for Hays. We are 30%
below consensus for Page in 17e and 29% below for Hays.

BE

Valuation and risk

At turning points in the cycle we believe that investors have little time for
through the cycle DCF valuations. We change our valuation methodology on
Hays and Page from DCF based valuations to setting our target prices using
EV/Gross Profit. We set our target price using a 2017e EV/Gross Profit of 1.5x
for PageGroup (vs. 15% conversion) and 2.0x for Hays (vs. 20% conversion).
This implies a share price target of 290p or 27% downside for PageGroup and
a target price of 105p or 23% downside for Hays. We prefer to use EV/Gross
Profit vs. EV/Sales due to the differences in temp/perm mix.

BE

For PageGroup - Upside risks include faster GDP growth than expected,
stronger growth in later cycle clerical and professional markets as well as
permanent recruitment markets (~70% of gross profit), better pricing and mix
benefits, lower impact of new competition and technology and greater cost
savings leading to more EBITA stability than we model.

11:18 am
BE

For Hays - Upside risks include faster GDP growth than expected (particularly
in the UK due to tax losses which results in high gearing), stronger growth in
later cycle clerical and professional markets, stronger than anticipated
performance in public sector markets, better pricing and mix benefits, lower
impact of new competition and technology and greater cost savings leading to
more EBITA stability than we model.

Pagegroup PLC (PAGE:LSE): Last: 373.00, down 26 (-6.52%), High: 388.00, Low: 370.30, Volume: 172.81k
Hays PLC (HAS:LSE): Last: 127.10, down 7.9 (-5.85%), High: 130.00, Low: 124.00, Volume: 3.20m
11:20 am
undefined
BE

@Nichoman, unsure where the Nestle-Hershey story appeared from ....

BE

..... Seems to have done the rounds at the US market open yesterday.

11:23 am
BE

The story being that Nestle took a pop at Hershey in 2002

BE

But was blocked by the Hershey Trust

BE

You'll remember similar rumours around Cadbury appearing quite often.

11:24 am
BE

What's worth noting, I guess, is that Hershey doesn't seem to be pimping itself up for a sale.

BE

Note the promotion a few days ago of Michele Buck to COO.

BE

The standard promotion path for Hershey is from COO to CEO, so one assumes that's where she's headed.

11:26 am
BE

Dave West and J.P. Bilbrey both followed that path.

BE

Brokers also noting Ms Buck is on a $5m retention bonus, which is about five times the size of the next-biggest set of golden handcuffs.

BE

However, I have no info either way on whether something significant has changed with the Trust. Instead, want to read about Credit Suisse's visit to the National Confectionery Association trade show in Chicago?

11:28 am
BE

Why wouldn't you?

BE

We attended the National Confectionery Association trade show in Chicago
and met with Hershey management to get a closer look at the industry's
product innovation plans for the rest of 2016. Unfortunately we came away
rather underwhelmed by the offerings and concerned that the confectionery
category will continue to lose share-of-mouth to alternative snacks. Hershey,
Mars, and Mondelez' products lacked the energy one would expect from
category leaders. A selfie taken by the author with tennis superstar Maria
Sharapova from her Sugarpova candy booth (available upon request) proved
to be the highlight of the day.

BE

Robert Moskow is the analyst, if you want to contact him directly for that selfie.

11:29 am
BE

Hershey having trouble adjusting to the new demand landscape for
snacks. The majority of Hershey's new products for 2016 departed from the
"hand-to-mouth" platform that proved so successful for Hershey in the early
2010's. Pay Day and Reese's snack size items were on display, but the only
new thing about them was the all-too familiar rigid plastic package designed
for car consoles. Most of the attention went toward two new King-size
products (Reese's Big Cup with Reese's Pieces and a thicker Kit Kat bar), a
new Cadbury bagged product for the premium segment, and a mishmash of
new varieties in healthy snacking including new Brookside bars, new flavors
of Krave, and the recently acquired BarkTHINS brand. Hershey also
dedicated space to the Allen candy business, which makes low-priced hard
candy for discount channels.
■ Hershey management says that these offerings reflect the company's new
strategic approach to reaching an increasingly bifurcated set of consumers
with vastly different purchasing power. But we walked away feeling that the
company is pulling itself in too many directions at once. For example, while
we agree with management's assertion that it needs to adapt to the growing
consumer desire for healthier protein-rich snacks outside of confectionery,
we don't quite get how the acquisitions of small brands within that space (like
Krave in meat snacks or BarkThins in healthier chocolate) will move the
needle for such a big company. The Brookside brand's 23% decline since
last year and its poor attempt to extend into snack bars indicates that the
company still struggles to sustain a health and wellness proposition. In
addition, we fear that investing in Allen Candy will steer the company into
lower-priced, less differentiated product lines.

BE

I see the bulb's still gone from the "Markets Live" light on the homepage.

undefined
11:31 am
BE

(@Londonbus: sorry, I don't have the mental capacity left to follow Anglo Irish Bank.)

BE

breaking news RUSSIAN CENTRAL BANK LOWERS KEY RATE TO 10.5%, MATCHING EST.

BE

11:32 am
undefined
BE

(@fjp73: NFI.)

BE

What else then? Every conversation in the office so far has been about Brexit coverage and England's Euro 2016 lineup ...

11:33 am
BE

.... Let's stick with the former.

BE

Citi negative on asset managers. Says Brexit is bad no matter what happens.

BE

Leave = slower growth, higher inflation, weaker £

11:35 am
BE

Remain = weak fund flows and poor investor sentiment

BE

(Post a wee relief bounce, one assumes)

BE

Impact of a Vote to Leave
Uncertainty associated with a Leave result (at least 2 years to negotiate a new relationship with the EU) and potential knock-on effects (second Scottish referendum, boost for other separatist movements in Europe, political instability in the UK) mean Brexit could have a negative impact not only for the UK, but in other regions too. Our economists see a potential 1.0-1.5% cut to UK GDP growth forecasts over the next 2-3 years, a 15-20% depreciation of sterling, a return to import-driven inflation and significant policy dilemma for the MPC.
Remain Also Not Without Risk
A Remain vote would likely be positively received by the markets, but is also not without risk. The key will be the margin of a Remain outcome: if it is a Close Remain result, then a sustained period of market risk and uncertainty seems likely, with continued political instability, a “Neverendum” situation, and increased friction between the EU and the UK on an ongoing basis.
Asset Managers
We think most UK asset managers would suffer in a post-Brexit scenario of slower UK growth, higher inflation and weaker sterling because of the associated negative moves in the UK equity markets. Conversely, a vote to Remain is likely to see a short-term bounce in share prices. However, we caution that the dampening effect on investor sentiment (and fund flows) of ongoing uncertainty – either due to an Out vote or a Close Remain vote – should not be underestimated. Year to date, net retail UK equity fund investor flows have been negative, and have worsened each month. Based on the proportion of AUM managed for UK retail clients and invested in equity, we see the greatest potential negative impact of a Leave or Close Remain outcome for: Hargreaves Lansdown and Jupiter. In a Clear Remain outcome, we see the most potential for re-rating for Schroders.
Exchanges/IDBs
Any outcome = relief. Recent market participation levels have dropped, with investors apparently sitting on their hands ahead of the referendum result. Volumes have come down materially from their Q1 highs. We believe this will begin to reverse once the result of the referendum is known, whichever way it goes. We see this return to trading as beneficial for the Exchanges and IDBs.

11:37 am
BE

Sell Aberdeen Hargreaves, Jupiter, Man.

BE

Buy Henderson, Ashmore.

BE

Don't bother with the rest.

11:37 am

11:40 am
BE

I think the volcano goes off in the Battle Royale when investors, who are currently flirting, stop sitting on their hands.

BE

And that's after four paragraphs of the front page. It's the Rosetta Stone of mixed metaphors.

BE

Binary outcome with three scenarios

11:41 am
BE

omg smile

BE

The referendum presents a binary outcome, however, Tina Fordham, Citi's Chief Political Analyst, sees three scenarios which investors need to consider — Leave, solid Remain and close Remain. There are different consequences in each scenario, as summarised in Figure 9. For example, in a Leave scenario, Tina anticipates additional clamour for a second Scottish referendum, as well as a new PM to replace David Cameron, who would likely resign.

BE

11:43 am
BE

Cripes. It's all too much for a Friday.

undefined
BE

Results wise, there's nothing much.

11:44 am
BE

Fuller's is about the most interesting on the tape.

BE

Current sales look a bit weak.

Fuller Smith & Turner PLC (FSTA:LSE): Last: 1,026, down 48.52 (-4.51%), High: 1,075, Low: 1,026, Volume: 13.09k
11:45 am
BE

With FY slightly ahead.

BE

Here's Numis to summarise.

BE

Full year adjusted PBT rose 12% to £40.9m, nicely ahead of our forecast of £39.5m,
with earnings up 13% to 58.4p. The total dividend is up 8% to 17.9p. There was a
4.8% rise in managed LFL sales and a 2% increase in tenanted LFL profits, which
was ahead of the market. Total beer and cider volumes were down by 1%, but profits
were maintained. We are increasing our FY17E PBT forecast by 3% to £42.9m.
● Managed pub/hotel LFL sales rose 4.8% (vs. a 6.3% comp), with food up 6.9%
and strong growth in premium wine and coffee. Margins improved 70bps to 13.0%.
Accommodation continues to play a key role, but trading has been impacted by a drop
in London tourism and a more competitive market.
● Tenanted LFL profits were up 2% and average EBITDA per pub increased by 2%
to £83,000. Brewing revenue rose by 5% to £126.8m, beer and cider volumes were
down by 1% but EBIT was flat at £7.6m, reflecting a strategic change in mix to
more premium products. The craft beer range was extended with growth in sales and
distribution of Oliver’s Island, Frontier Craft Lager and Cornish Orchards Cider.
● Fuller's acquired five new pubs, opened one new build and purchased three existing
freeholds. In addition, record levels of investment in the existing estate is generating
strong returns. Six new ‘Stable’ (craft cider and gourmet pizza) sites were opened in
the year and this acquisition continues to flourish.
● Current Trading. Managed LFLs are up by 2.7% in first 10 weeks with tenanted LFL
profits down 2%; this reflects tough comps, Easter and a particularly poor April. May
was better. Total beer and cider volumes are down 5%, reflecting the loss of sales to
Spirit (Greene King). Record investment is planned for the existing estate in FY17 and
management believes that it is “well-positioned for the future, with a solid, proven longterm
business model and strong balance sheet.”

11:46 am
BE

It has been another successful year for Fuller's and, whilst trading conditions at
the start of FY17 are more challenging, we believe that the company is well placed
to continue its excellent record of profitable growth. The marketplace is changing,
with an increasingly demanding consumer looking for quality and authenticity.
Fuller's is well placed to meet these demands with a management team committed
to innovation, investment and staying ahead of the game.

BE

(@Soundbuy: I've some stuff on that somewhere. Hold on.)

BE

And Panmure.

11:47 am
BE

Fuller’s has reported FY results for 52 weeks to 26 March 2016 with strong
trading in the period. Total revenues increase by 9% to £350.5m, driven by
managed LFL sales growth of 4.8%, PBT increase by +12% to £40.9m (PGe
£39.5m) giving EPS +13% to 58.35p (PGe 55.0p). Current trading has slowed to
+2.7%, beer and cider volumes -5% although this is impacted by short time
period and calendar impact. Additionally, the company has purchased an
addition 25% stake in The Stable post year end, bringing the total to 76%. We
do not expect to make major changes to our forecast assumptions ahead of the
presentation later today. The stock trades on 11.2x EV/EBITDA 2017E, a
premium to the sector and we retain our Hold recommendation.
 FY16 Results: Revenue +9% to £350.5m, EBITDA +11% to £65m, Adj PBT +12% to
£40.9m, adjust EPS +13% to 58.35p, DPS +8% to 17.9p. LFL sales +4.8% in managed
pubs with tenanted LFL profits +2%. Beer and cider volumes -1%.
 Estate development. Acquired 5 new pubs (including a newly built pub in Greenwich
Reach called The Sail Loft) and 3 freeholds of existing pubs. Additionally acquired 51%
stake in Nectar Imports, a wholesale drinks business. In addition opened 6 new ‘The
Stable’ sites. Since the year end the company has purchased an additional 25% of The
Stable taking the total stake to 76%. Current year plans include 7 schemes completed
and four more underway.
 Current Trading +2.7% in the first 10 weeks of the year with tenanted profits down
2% and beer volumes -5% -up against challenging comps. We have LFL growth of
+2.5% in our forecasts for 2017E and do not expect to make any significant
adjustments other than for The Stable investment.
 Conclusion and recommendation. Fullers trades on a 2017E PER of 18.6x and an
EV/EBITDA ratio of 11.2x, yielding 2.1%. This is a premium to its pub & restaurant
sector peer group trading on average EV/EBITDA ratio of 9.6x and a premium to its
closest peer Young’s on 10.5x EV/EBITDA. We maintain our Hold recommendation
and continue to prefer Young’s given its stronger LFL trading, no exposure to brewing
higher margins and higher FCF yield.

BE

How long's Panmure been putting pen pics of its analysts on its notes?

BE

Here's Anna Barnfather, who wrote the above.

11:49 am
BE

undefined
BE

Okay, on craft beer, my go-to analyst is Pablo Zuanic at SIG

11:51 am
BE

This is US focused, of course, and one can make a long argument about the differences between the US and UK markets for beer.

BE

Nevertheless ........

BE

Summary: Craft beer volumes grew by 17% again in 2015 (as in 2014), according to IRI, and are up 55% cumulatively over the past three years (we exclude Boston Beer and Yuengling from our estimates). On the other hand, non-craft domestic beer (81% of industry sales volumes including imports) fell 2% over those three years. Despite the headlines and accelerating consolidation pace (craft brewers merging, big brewers buying them), craft beer penetration still remains low at 5.5% of domestic production (given imports are 13% of beer sales in the U.S., the craft market share of total sales volumes is 4.7%) excluding SAM and Yuengling (including them, craft would be 8.7% of domestic production). But the space remains fiercely competitive and not all are doing well: among the top six craft brewers, only Sierra Nevada and Lagunitas posted double-digit growth in 2015, with New Belgium and Craft Brew Alliance only growing 1%. The space still remains quite fragmented, with brewers outside the top 20 accounting for 43% of craft, and growing above the craft average. Increased craft competition at the local level may pressure the bigger brewers. Still, craft penetration varies widely at the state level (VT 41%, OR 31%, WA 26%, CO 25%) so we would expect BUD and TAP (and others) to continue to romp to beef up market shares in states where they lag, but we would caution on taking all the acquired brands nationwide (ex a few exceptions).

11:52 am
BE

The excellent Trevor Sterling at Bernstein has also covered the area in some depth.

BE

Slightly randomly, here's some of his thesis on the subject from 2014.

BE

[A] subject of much heated debate – what is
a craft beer? The industry association of craft brewers is the
Brewers Association (BA). However, their definition focuses as
much on the size of the brewery and its ownership as the quality
of the liquid. The BA definition is that a craft brewer should be:
Small (annual production 6m barrels of beer or less, approx 3%
US national share, recently increased from 2m barrels/1%);
Independent (less than 25%-owned by another non-craft alcoholic
beverage industry member, which excludes those breweries where
ABI has a major stake but not those craft brewers which are
owned by smaller foreign breweries); and Traditional (a majority
of their total beverage alcohol volume from beers whose flavour
derives from traditional or innovative brewing ingredients and
their fermentation, used to be 50% based on malted barley). Now,
I have no problem with this as the rules of membership of an
industry association. But it excludes high quality liquids made by
brewers who are part- or wholly owned by the majors (e.g. Goose
Island) and it excludes imported ales, stouts, German pils, etc.
There is also the anomaly that beer which is contract-brewed for a
'craft' brewer by a major brewer counts as craft beer; but if the
exact same liquid were sold by the major brewer under its own
brand, that would not be craft beer. So in our definition of 'Beer
with Attitude' we supplement the BA beer volumes (exemplified
by Boston Beer's Sam Adams) with our own somewhat arbitrary
list: e.g. adding Goose Island & Leinenkugel's, Blue Moon &
Shock Top3 and Guinness & Newcastle Brown Ale.

11:54 am
BE

On this basis, Beer with Attitude has gone from a 4% volume
share of US beer in 2003 to almost 12% today, of
which approx 8% are BA-defined craft beers. Furthermore, with
an average revenue per barrel that is approx 50% higher than
mainstream beer, Beer with Attitude accounts for a high teens
value share of US beer.

BE

So ........

BE

11:55 am
BE

∑ Ignore these more challenging styles of beer at your peril.
Over time, tastes evolve and it seems inevitable that
consumers will want to differentiate themselves from the
mainstream.
∑ It's not inevitable that small brewers drive the rise of Beer
with Attitude, though they often do, as large brewers
initially often ignore the sector. Undoubtedly, there is a
body of consumers for whom authenticity is inextricably
tied up with size; but arguably there are many more
consumers for whom taste and heritage are even more
important.
∑ Being successful in Beer with Attitude will inevitably
bring much more fragmentation and SKU complexity;
but as long as you get your price-positioning right, the
higher gross margin more than compensates for the costof-complexity
∑ Selling Beer with Attitude arguably needs a separate
sales-force from mainstream beer. Most successful Beer
with Attitude brands are more built by word-of-mouth
and passion, rather than advertising and super-market
placement. I doubt if Leffe and Hoegaarden would have
been so successful in France if ABI had already had a
large mainstream lager to defend.
∑ Don't sell or close down your heritage; you never know
when it will come in handy. Several of the large UK
brewers sold their ale brands, or milked them, or focused
only on keg ale at the expense of cask and bottled, and as
a result left the door completely open for regional and
micro brewers. For example, in response to these trends
Coors UK preferred to buy a 'new' ale brand founded in
1994 (Doom Bar from Sharp's Brewery) rather than
renovate one of their own heritage brands.

BE

Trevor's stuff is great. Bribe or blackmail whoever you can to get on his mailing list.

undefined
11:57 am
BE

12:09 pm

BE

BE

Afternoon, all.

11:29 am
BE

■ The Investor Day in October marks the next big catalyst for Hershey stock.
Hershey plans to unveil more details about the consumer research it has done to
reboot its demand-landscape strategy at its upcoming analyst day. This new approach
presumably will include a better understanding of and a more thought-out approach to
reaching the healthy snacker and the low income snacker. In addition, we expect to
hear more from management about how it intends to maintain and grow its gross
margin, which looks rather "peak-ish" to us at 46.8%.
■ What does this mean for the stock? Despite the rather unimpressive offerings,
management didn't sound like it had any immediate concerns about its earnings
forecast for the year. Perhaps this is in part because it is in the midst of a 2Q that is
enjoying the benefit of new product pipeline fill. The real question on management's
mind appears to be whether consumer spending in the U.S. category (now barely 1%)
will get back to a more normal pace in the second half of the year. The struggling
Chinese business shows no sign of a rebound, so the business plan relies heavily on a
stronger domestic market. Unfortunately the slate of product innovation did not do
much to ignite our hopes for domestic growth.
